main_objective.title: Main Objective
main_objective.description1: MathSolver was created with a simple mission: to make mathematics accessible, comprehensible, and less intimidating for people of all ages.
main_objective.description2: The main goal is not just to provide answers, but to foster true understanding of mathematical concepts. By offering step-by-step explanations alongside solutions, students learn to develop problem-solving skills that will accompany them throughout their academic journey.

educational_philosophy.title: Educational Philosophy
educational_philosophy.description1: At MathSolver, understanding the 'why' behind mathematical processes is as important as knowing the 'how'. This approach emphasizes conceptual understanding along with procedural fluency.
educational_philosophy.description2: The explanations are designed to be clear, concise, and accessible to people with different levels of mathematical proficiency.

alternative_notations.title: Alternative Notations
alternative_notations.description: Different mathematical disciplines use various notations for the transpose:
alternative_notations.left_superscript: <sup>t</sup>A - Left superscript (used in some European literature)

inner_products.title: Relationship to Inner Products
inner_products.description: For vectors u and v, the inner product can be expressed using transpose: ⟨u,v⟩ = u<sup>T</sup>v. This relationship extends to matrices where A<sup>T</sup>B represents a generalization of the dot product.

computational.title: Computational Performance
computational.description: Matrix transposition has O(n²) time complexity for n×n matrices. However, modern libraries often use cache-optimized algorithms and lazy evaluation techniques to improve performance. In many numerical libraries, transposition is implemented as a "view" rather than physically rearranging data in memory.

special_classes.title: Special Matrix Classes
special_classes.description: Several matrix classes have special transpose properties:
special_classes.hermitian: Hermitian matrices: A = A<sup>H</sup> (complex conjugate transpose)
